questions.text: Which of the following can be used as a yardstick for the assessment of standards of therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Survival rate measures the proportion of individuals who remain alive after a specified time following diagnosis or initiation of treatment.
  • It reflects prognosis and is a direct indicator of the effectiveness of therapy, making it a valuable yardstick for assessing treatment standards.

Survival rate:

  • Survival rate refers to the proportion of individuals in a specific group (e.g., patients with a certain disease) who remain alive after being observed for a defined period, such as 5 years.
  • It is an important measure for describing the prognosis of a disease and is widely used as a yardstick to assess the standards of therapy.
  • The survival period is usually calculated from the date of diagnosis or the start of treatment.
  • Survival rates are especially important in evaluating outcomes in cancer studies, where they help compare the effectiveness of different treatment modalities.

Kaplan-Meier Survival Analysis: A non-parametric statistical method used to estimate the survival function from lifetime data, that is, the probability of surviving for a certain length of time after treatment or diagnosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Specific Death Rate(Option A): Death rate in a specific population group (by age, sex, occupation, etc.) or from a specific cause. Describes mortality patterns, not therapy effectiveness.

Case Fatality Rate (Option B): Proportion of individuals with a disease who die from it within a specified period. Reflects severity and lethality of disease, not necessarily therapy standards.

Proportional Mortality Rate(Option C): Proportion of all deaths due to a particular cause in a given population.Shows relative importance of a cause of death in the community, not therapy outcomes.

Proportional mortality rate: PMR expresses the proportion of all deaths that are due to a particular cause (e.g., cancer) or occurring in a specific age group (e.g., above 50 years) during a given period. It is generally expressed per 100 or 1,000 total deaths.

Proportional mortality rate from TB = 10/100x100 = 10%

Key Features:

  • Usually calculated for broad disease groups (e.g., communicable diseases) or specific major public health problems (e.g., cancer, coronary heart disease).
  • Useful when population data is not available.
  • Indicates the relative importance of a disease or age group as a cause of death in a given population.

Limitations:

  • Depends on two variables (cause-specific deaths and total deaths), both of which may vary between places or periods.
  • Not suitable for comparing risk between different populations or periods.
  • Does not measure the actual risk of contracting or dying from the disease.

Public Health Significance:

  • Helps in priority setting within the same population (e.g., high proportionate mortality from communicable diseases signals the need for preventive action).
  • It can be calculated separately by age and sex to guide targeted interventions.

questions.text: Which of the following is a mortality indicator?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Life expectancy:

  • The average number of years that a person is expected to live from a given age, if the age-specific mortality rates of the given period continue throughout the person's life.
  • Life expectancy is a positive mortality indicator and part of life table analysis.
  • It can be calculated at birth (most common) or from any other age.
  • Computed from current age-specific death rates.
  • Higher life expectancy → lower mortality in the population.
  • Used for health planning and to compare health status between countries or over time.
  • India's life expectancy at birth is given using SRS (Sample Registration System) data, around 69-70 years

Explanation of Other Options:

Notification rate(Option B): Measures how many cases of a particular disease are officially reported in a population per period. The notification rate is a morbidity indicator

DALY(Option C): Disability Adjusted Life Year, Combines Years of Life Lost (YLL) due to premature death + Years Lived with Disability (YLD). It is a disability indicator

Bed turnover ratio(Option D): Measures the number of times a hospital bed is used by different patients during a given period. It is a Health utilization indicator

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly used as an indicator for measuring the burden of disease in a community?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Prevalence is a measure of the burden of disease in a population in a given location and at a particular time, as represented in a count of the number of people affected. Counts of the number of people affected by a disease are required to plan appropriately for their health care needs

Types of Prevalence:

  • Point Prevalence: Defined as all existing cases at a single point in time.

  • Period Prevalence: Defined as all existing cases during a defined period (e.g., a year), including cases that started before the period but continued into it.

Uses of Prevalence:

  • Estimates the magnitude of health/disease problems.
  • Identifies high-risk groups.
  • Health planning: hospital beds, manpower, rehabilitation facilities.
  • Monitoring chronic diseases where the duration is long.

Limitations:

  • Not ideal for studying disease causation (confounded by duration).
  • Better for planning & burden estimation than for identifying risk factors.
  • Incidence is preferred for etiological studies.

Explanation of Other Options:

Crude Death Rate(Option A): Total number of deaths in a year per 1000 mid-year population. Measures overall mortality, not disease-specific burden.

Cause-specific Death Rate(Option C): Number of deaths due to a specific cause in a year per 100,000 (or 1,000) population. Compares mortality between diseases (e.g., deaths due to TB vs cancer). Reflects fatality, not total burden (doesn't count non-fatal cases).

Proportional Mortality Rate(Option D): Percentage of deaths due to a specific disease out of total deaths in a given year. Shows the relative contribution of a disease to overall mortality.

questions.text: All the following are true about standardization except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Indirect standardization apply age-specific rates of the standard population to the study population's age distribution.

Standardization:

  • Method of removing age disparity in populations before comparing
  • Removes the confounding effect of age structures, yielding a single standardized or adjusted rate by which mortality experiences can be compared
  • Yield Standardized or Adjusted rate for comparing mortality
  • Standardization allows comparison to be made between two different populations(Option A ruled out)
  • Standardization is of two types- Direct and Indirect

Direct Standardization:

Purpose is to compare rates (e.g., mortality) between populations with different age structures and Removes the effect of age distribution differences.
Steps in Direct Standardization:

  • Select a standard population
    • Known numbers in each age/sex group.
    • Can be a real population (e.g., national population). A combined/created population (sum of compared groups).
  • Obtain age-specific rates for the study population. Example: death rates per 1,000 in each age group.
  • Apply the study population's age-specific rates to the standard population → gives expected deaths in each age group.
  • Sum the expected deaths for all age groups.
  • Divide total expected deaths by total standard population gives standardized rate.

Note: Apply age-specific rates of the study population to the standard population's age distribution.(Option C ruled out)

Indirect standardization:

Produces Standardized Mortality Ratio

Standardized Mortality Ratio: Ratio of observed deaths in study group to expected deaths (if study group had same age-specific rates as standard pop.).

Advantages of Indirect Method:

  • Works when age-specific rates in study group are unavailable or unstable (small numbers).
  • Only need Population in each age group (study pop.) and Age-specific rates from standard population.
  • Can be used for disease occurrence, not just death.

Note: Apply age-specific rates of the standard population to the study population's age distribution.

The standard population used is:

  • Segi world population
  • European standard population
  • National population(Option B ruled out)
  • The available population may be used

questions.text: The crude mortality rate in Community A was higher than the crude mortality rate in Community B, but the age-adjusted mortality rate was higher in Community B than in Community A. This indicates that:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The crude mortality rate in Community A was higher than the crude mortality rate in Community B because old age people were more in Community A. But after standardisation, which removed age disparity, making age structure in Population A and B comparable, age age-adjusted rate (Age standardised rate) was higher in Population B

Understanding crude vs. age-adjusted mortality rate:

  • Crude mortality rate is total deaths / total population (not accounting for age structure).
  • Age-adjusted mortality rate is rate calculated after adjusting for differences in age distribution between populations. This removes the effect of having more elderly or more young people.

A high crude mortality in Community A may be due to a larger proportion of older people (who naturally have higher death rates), not because the age-specific death rates are worse.

After age adjustment, the effect of having more elderly in A is removed. If B's adjusted rate becomes higher, it means B actually has worse age-specific mortality rates, but A's crude rate looked worse initially due to an older age distribution.

questions.text: The incidence rate of a disease is 5 times greater in women than in men, but the prevalence rate shows no sex difference. The best explanation is that
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Given:

  • Incidence rate: 5 times higher in women than men
  • Prevalence rate: No difference between sexes

  • If incidence is much higher in women but prevalence is the same in both sexes, it means duration must be shorter in women to offset the higher incidence.
  • Shorter duration can occur if Women recover faster Or women die faster from the disease (i.e., higher case fatality rate)

Explanation of Other Options:

The Crude Death Rate is greater in women(Option A): Crude death rate is total deaths from all causes per 1000 population per year. It's not disease-specific, so even if women have higher crude death rate, it doesn't explain why prevalence of this particular disease is the same.

The Case Fatality rate for this disease is lower in women(Option C): Lower case fatality means women survive longer with the disease which implies longer duration. Given women already have higher incidence, a longer duration would make prevalence in women much higher, not equal.

Disease duration is shorter in men(Option D): Shorter duration in men means prevalence in men would be lower than women (since women have both higher incidence and longer duration in that case).

Incidence rate:

The incidence rate measures the occurrence of new cases of a disease in a specified population during a defined period of time.

  • Refers only to new cases.
  • Measured over a specific time period (commonly 1 year).
  • Calculated in a specified population at risk (unless another denominator is chosen).
  • Can also measure new episodes or spells of diseases that may occur more than once in a person during the period. Example: If a person suffers from the common cold twice in a year, both episodes are counted separately.

Uses of Incidence Rate:

  • Disease Control:
    • Rising incidence may indicate failure or ineffectiveness of current control programs.
    • May suggest the need for new preventive or therapeutic interventions.
  • Research Purposes:
    • Study aetiology (causes) and pathogenesis.
    • Evaluate efficacy of preventive and therapeutic measures.
    • Understand distribution of disease in populations.
  • Surveillance & Planning:
    • Comparing incidence rates across socio-economic groups or geographical areas can reveal health service gaps.
    • Changes in incidence may indicate:
      • Shift in disease-causing agents
      • Change in host factors
      • Change in environmental conditions
      • Improved disease reporting systems
